alert.note: Alert for Graham (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 29 at 10:22PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 415 AM EDT WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of western North Carolina, including the following county, Graham. * WHEN...Until 415 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, hiking trails and boat-access areas. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1016 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms occurring mainly over the Snowbird Wilderness Area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen over the past 90 minutes. This is likely to produce excessive runoff and rapid rises on small streams within the rural and uninhabited areas of western Graham County. Backpackers and campers should exercise caution on area hiking trails and avoid low-lying areas near streams for the next few hours. - Thunderstorms continue over the area and additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected. This additional rain will exacerbate high flows and bankfull conditions. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Robbinsville, Snowbird, and Town Of Santeetlah. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
